- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.

<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl:
```c
void OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(const char *Str, size_t DataLen)
{
    ssize_t WriteLen;

    while (DataLen > 0)
    {
        /* writes the raw data directly to STDOUT_FILENO (unbuffered) */
        WriteLen = write(STDOUT_FILENO, Str, DataLen);
        if (WriteLen <= 0)
        {
            /* no recourse if this fails, just stop. */
            break;
        }
        Str += WriteLen;
        DataLen -= WriteLen;
    }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: /* writes the raw data directly to STDOUT_FILENO (unbuffered) */
explanation: All other code constructs in this function are standard ISO C and do not appear to rely on compiler language extensions: the function signature (void OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(const char *, size_t)), use of size_t, the while loop, if check, pointer arithmetic (Str += WriteLen), subtraction (DataLen -= WriteLen), break, and return type void are all standard C. The only items that require further investigation are those that reference POSIX/platform-specific APIs or types (ssize_t, write(), STDOUT_FILENO); everything else is ordinary, portable C and therefore need not be investigated for Rule 1.2.
